bibl.title: Letter from P.M. Hamer to Philip Showalter Hench, June 28, 1941

div1.p: Hamer is sending copies of the requested documents, but informs Hench that most of the documents he has requested are scattered through too many files for his staff to find and copy. He invites Hench to come and examine the documents himself.

div1.head: Letter from P.M. Hamer to Philip Showalter Hench, June 28, 1941
div1.opener:
THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES OF THE UNITED STATES
1934
DIVISION OF REFERENCE
The National Archives
Washington, D. C.
JUN 28 1941
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
My dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
In compliance with your request of June 2, we are sending
under separate cover copies of documents as listed on the
enclosure. These documents are from the records of the War
Department which are now in the custody of The National Archives.

The material described in our letter of May 24, is con-
tained in the records of the War Department which have been
transferred to The National Archives. It is scattered through
many files, and to provide a detailed list of it would involve
more extensive research than our limited staff can undertake.
It is probable that only a personal examination of the documents
would reveal their value for your purposes. We shall be pleased
to make these documents available for that purpose and to extend
all the facilities at our disposal.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, P. M. Hamer, Chief
